DOC.HEAD: Egypt, Syria To Be Reconciled
DOC.TEXT: A top-level Syrian envoy said Saturday the presidents of Egypt and Syria will soon meet to put an end to a 12-year rift. The emissary, Vice President Abdel-Halim Khaddam, strongly indicated after talks with President Hosni Mubarak that the two countries will resume diplomatic relations. Khaddam, the highest ranking Syrian official to visit Egypt since 1977, arrived Saturday with what he called ``a message of amity and brotherhood'' from President Hafez Assad to the Egyptian leader. ``The coming meeting between the two presidents will lead to practical and concrete results in rectifying the status of Egyptian-Syrian relations,'' Khaddam told reporters after conferring privately with Mubarak for about 1{ hours. Asked specifically whether the summit would bring restored diplomatic ties, Khaddam said: ``When we speak about rectifying the status of relations, we mean a comprehensive approach, not a narrow one.'' Egypt and Syria together fought Israel in the 1973 Middle East war, but Syria broke ties four years later in response to then-President Anwar Sadat's historic visit to Jerusalem in November 1977, which led to a peace treaty. Syria was only one of 17 Arab states that broke ties with Egypt over its peace initiative with Israel. All but Syria and Libya have since renewed ties. Khaddam said the summit ``will be in the very near future.'' He said Assad and Mubarak would decide where and when to meet. Egyptian-Libyan relations improved considerably this year without full diplomatic reconciliation. Mubarak and Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi have met three times since October and have agreed on broad economic cooperation between their countries.
